G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action is brought in the Massachusetts Housing Court, Western Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, which grants the Housing Court jurisdiction over actions arising out of the occupation of residential premises and the landlord–tenant relationship.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 8, and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts, which lies within the territorial jurisdiction of the Housing Court, Western Division.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides, in pertinent part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that a landlord who does so shall be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord, or someone acting under his control, commits acts or omissions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets the Massachusetts statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord that foreseeably interferes with the tenant’s rights. While the case’s primary issue is whether strict statutory lead-paint liability alone triggers § 14 (it does not), the court reaffirms that a breach of the covenant occurs when the landlord, through acts or omissions involving some degree of fault, substantially interferes with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment. That aligns with the proposition stated.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures. … [T]he ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord, or someone acting under his control, commits acts or omissions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law and explains that it protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions or what the landlord permits to be done. The court states that a breach occurs when serious interference is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and applies that standard to the landlord’s failure to act against drug activity in common areas. This aligns with the proposition that acts or omissions by the landlord or those under its control that substantially interfere with beneficial use and enjoyment breach the covenant.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: A landlord’s failure, after notice, to repair serious defects in facilities and services he is obligated to provide can constitute an “indirect interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 through indirect interference where the disturbance is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted and where he has control to correct the condition. The specific facts involve noise from a lounge, not failure to repair physical defects, but the court’s reasoning expressly rejects a malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction and cites prior cases involving failure to supply services (heat, light, power) as examples of such indirect interference. Thus, by analogy and doctrinal statement, the opinion supports the proposition, though not on identical facts.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services)… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling."

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–48 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: A landlord’s failure, after notice, to repair serious defects in facilities and services he is obligated to provide can constitute an “indirect interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and notes that serious interference plus landlord notice and negligence can create a violation. However, it does not articulate or apply a rule that a landlord’s failure, after notice, to repair serious defects in required facilities or services constitutes an indirect interference with quiet enjoyment; instead, it finds no interference because the landlord promptly repaired the conditions. The specific “indirect interference” via failure to repair principle is not developed or endorsed here.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when conditions at the premises, caused or allowed to persist by the landlord, materially impair the character and value of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment using the exact formulation that a violation occurs where the landlord’s acts or omissions cause serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. The court quotes earlier precedent for this definition and explains that “quiet enjoyment” means freedom from such serious interferences. This directly aligns with the claimed proposition about when the covenant is violated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]).”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the implied warranty of habitability requires that a residential unit comply with the State Sanitary Code and be fit for human habitation, and that serious code violations or failures in essential services can also support claims for breach of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The concurrence/dissent explicitly ties the landlord’s obligation to an implied undertaking that the dwelling meet “minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation” as defined by the State Sanitary Code, and that breach affects the tenant’s rent obligation. That squarely supports the habitability/Code-compliance part of the proposition. This portion, however, does not itself discuss G.L. c. 186, §14 or ‘quiet enjoyment’; any link between serious code violations and breach of quiet enjoyment comes from the majority opinion and Massachusetts law more generally, not from the quoted concurring/dissenting text alone.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… [It] fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant….”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A, 127H.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the implied warranty of habitability requires that a residential unit comply with the State Sanitary Code and be fit for human habitation, and that serious code violations or failures in essential services can also support claims for breach of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the implied warranty of habitability requires that a residential unit comply with the State Sanitary Code and be fit for human habitation, and that serious code violations or failures in essential services can also support claims for breach of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.254, 410.351\u2013410.355.proposition: The State Sanitary Code requires, among other things, that every dwelling unit be provided with sufficient electrical outlets and lighting and that electrical service be maintained in good working order.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and cases interpreting it, further recognize that substantial defects in essential services (including heat, water, and electricity) can constitute serious code violations and materially affect the health, safety, or well-being of tenants, warranting rent abatement or other relief.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and cases interpreting it, further recognize that substantial defects in essential services (including heat, water, and electricity) can constitute serious code violations and materially affect the health, safety, or well-being of tenants, warranting rent abatement or other relief.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties loss of heat and hot water to Sanitary Code violations, treats them as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability, and grounds the tenant’s right to withhold/abate rent in G.L. c. 239, § 8A and related legislative policy. It discusses § 8A’s evolution away from a landlord-fault standard and recognizes that code violations involving essential services (like heat and hot water) justify rent withholding and common-law rent abatement. This directly supports the proposition that substantial defects in essential services can be serious code violations materially affecting tenants and warranting rent abatement or other relief.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations only if ‘the owner . . . had not taken reasonable steps to remedy such conditions.’… In 1977, the Legislature struck this provision. … As was the case in Hemingway, this statute provides for rent withholding, not rent abatement; but, as in Hemingway, we choose to permit a rent abatement as a matter of common law.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–77 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: To the extent required and appropriate under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and applicable case law, Plaintiff seeks an award of three months’ rent ($3,600.00) as statutory damages in addition to, or in the alternative to, actual damages, as the statute and the Court permit.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (three months’ rent as statutory damages, in addition to or as an alternative to actual damages). Cruz Mgmt. v. Wideman addresses only breach of the implied warranty of habitability, calculation of compensatory damages based on contract rent, federal preemption issues, and mentions c. 186, § 14 only in passing via a citation to Simon v. Solomon. It does not interpret § 14’s statutory damages scheme, nor discuss treble-rent damages or their relationship to actual damages, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Recovery by Wideman based on the contract rent does not result in an improper diversion to her of public funds. A private landlord, like Cruz Management, is not shielded from liability to which the landlord would otherwise be exposed merely because a part of its income is derived from Federal subsidy funds. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 110 n.13 (1982) (permitting recovery of treble damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, calculated on contract rent, where tenant’s rent was subsidized).
